Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Broadening Participation in Engineering among Women and Latina/os: A Longitudinal, Multi-Site Study

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims to investigate the longitudinal effects of social cognitive, cultural, personality and contextual factors on engineering students and workers satisfaction, engagement, and persistence as posited by Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT). The longstanding underrepresentation of White women and Latina/os in engineering majors and jobs provides the rationale for this investigation of psychological factors leading to their academic and career satisfaction, engagement, and persistence.

Using data from a sample of engineering students at nine engineering colleges, the PIs propose to test the hypothesis that SCCT model will explain significant variance in engineering-related satisfaction, engagement, persistence. A structural equation modeling study of these factors will be complemented with a qualitative study of the individual and institutional factors. Intellectual merits of the project include: 1) A potentially conclusive examination of the utility of the SCCT model in predicting satisfaction, engagement, and persistence in engineering for White women and Latina/os both during college and early career stages; 2) Understanding the role of social cognitive, environmental and cultural factors in the satisfaction, engagement, and retention of White women and Latina/os in the engineering pipeline over time; 3) Advancing theory to explain engineering satisfaction, engagement, and persistence of Latina/os and White women in engineering; 4) Understanding factors influencing the persistence and non-persistence decisions of White women and Latina/o engineers; and 5) Developing reliable and valid measures to assess negative outcome expectations in engineering and engineering specific learning experiences.

Results from this work will inform the development of custom interventions to enhance relevant systemic supports and bolster the social cognitions that are the strongest predictors in engagement, persistence, and satisfaction in engineering for each group. The findings can also inform the development of supports at strategic points in students' educational training when they may be at higher risk for dropping out of engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We summarize outcomes from the largest scale, longitudinal retention study of an underrepresented minority group in engineering to date. This 5-year project investigated the longitudinal effects of social cognitive, personal, and contextual factors on engineering students’ persistence decisions using Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT: Lent et al., 1994; 2000) as the theoretical framework. Using both quantitative and qualitative research design, we sampled Latinas, Latinos, White men, and White women engineering majors enrolled at 11 partner institutions. In 2014-2015, we sampled 1,413 students, and we followed these participants across a span of 5 years. Intellectual merit outcomes include qualitative and quantitative evidence of: a) SCCT’s utility in explaining engagement, satisfaction, and persistence intentions of White women and Latinx engineering students, b) the critical role of social cognitive and environmental factors on persistence in engineering; in particular, self-efficacy and social supports were consistent strong predictors of engagement, satisfaction, and persistence, c) nonsignificant, single-group differences in associations within the model (i.e., Latinxs vs. Whites); however, findings pointed to differences in the SCCT model across intersectional groups (i.e., institutional differences among Latinx students; racial differences among PWI students), suggesting the importance of tailoring interventions for subgroups of engineering students, d) 4 themes (dominance of white male culture; resistance; psychological effects and practices; engineering identity) and 12 subthemes, which emerged from an analysis of interview data; these qualitative findings illustrated how Latinx students and women developed a strong engineering identity, which was grounded in their perceived fit within the culture of engineering, sense of purpose, and resistance to the dominance of white male culture. and e) 2 reliable and valid measures of Negative Outcome Expectations in Engineering and Engineering Learning Experiences. This project has resulted in 3 peer-reviewed publications, with an additional 2 currently under review and 2 in development, 1 peer-reviewed conference proceeding, and 35 conference presentations. The broader impact of this projects includes (a) generating theoretically-driven research with the largest racial minority group in the U.S. (Latinxs) that can contribute to increasing their representation in engineering, (b) substantial dissemination to professionals, including engineering faculty and administrators, who can use the results to inform interventions aimed at broadening participation in engineering, and (c) training future SCCT STEM researchers from URM groups. First, we are an experienced team that has conducted SCCT research in the engineering domain with Latinxs for almost 10 years; we are the only researchers that are programmatically applying SCCT with Latinx engineer samples. Second, we have presented findings from our projects to engineering faculty and administrators at participating institutions both in person and via webinars. Evaluations of these institutional presentations indicate that we were effective in translating these findings to engineering audiences. We have disseminated our findings extensively to professionals who can use our results to inform the creation and implementation of intervention programs that can bolster women and Latinx’ persistence in engineering. Further, we have delivered invited presentations at the University of Minnesota (Department of Psychology Colloquium Series), St. Mary’s College of Maryland (Department of Psychology Lecture Series), University of Missouri (Distinguished Lecture Series), and University of North Dakota (STEM Café, Faculty Lecture Series). Finally, we have trained 24 URM psychology students. These RAs have developed expertise in theoretically-driven research, understanding the career issues of women and Latinxs in engineering, and grant development. Their involvement has led to four dissertations and one master’s thesis on Latinx and women in engineering. Two former RAs are current faculty developing research lines on URMs in engineering. The PIs have mentored graduate students with interests in the career development of URMs. Our project website (http://nsfengineerstudy.org) contains a summary of the project and outputs. 

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2020
Modified by: Lisa Y Flores
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We summarize outcomes from the largest scale, longitudinal retention study of an underrepresented minority group in engineering to date. This 5-year project investigated the longitudinal effects of social cognitive, personal, and contextual factors on engineering students’ persistence decisions using Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT: Lent et al., 1994; 2000) as the theoretical framework. Using both quantitative and qualitative research design, we sampled Latinas, Latinos, White men, and White women engineering majors enrolled at 11 partner institutions. In 2014-2015, we sampled 1,413 students, and we followed these participants across a span of 5 years. Intellectual merit outcomes include qualitative and quantitative evidence of: a) SCCT’s utility in explaining engagement, satisfaction, and persistence intentions of White women and Latinx engineering students, b) the critical role of social cognitive and environmental factors on persistence in engineering; in particular, self-efficacy and social supports were consistent strong predictors of engagement, satisfaction, and persistence, c) nonsignificant, single-group differences in associations within the model (i.e., Latinxs vs. Whites); however, findings pointed to differences in the SCCT model across intersectional groups (i.e., institutional differences among Latinx students; racial differences among PWI students), suggesting the importance of tailoring interventions for subgroups of engineering students, d) 4 themes (dominance of white male culture; resistance; psychological effects and practices; engineering identity) and 12 subthemes, which emerged from an analysis of interview data; these qualitative findings illustrated how Latinx students and women developed a strong engineering identity, which was grounded in their perceived fit within the culture of engineering, sense of purpose, and resistance to the dominance of white male culture. and e) 2 reliable and valid measures of Negative Outcome Expectations in Engineering and Engineering Learning Experiences. This project has resulted in 3 peer-reviewed publications, with an additional 2 currently under review and 2 in development, 1 peer-reviewed conference proceeding, and 35 conference presentations. The broader impact of this projects includes (a) generating theoretically-driven research with the largest racial minority group in the U.S. (Latinxs) that can contribute to increasing their representation in engineering, (b) substantial dissemination to professionals, including engineering faculty and administrators, who can use the results to inform interventions aimed at broadening participation in engineering, and (c) training future SCCT STEM researchers from URM groups. First, we are an experienced team that has conducted SCCT research in the engineering domain with Latinxs for almost 10 years; we are the only researchers that are programmatically applying SCCT with Latinx engineer samples. Second, we have presented findings from our projects to engineering faculty and administrators at participating institutions both in person and via webinars. Evaluations of these institutional presentations indicate that we were effective in translating these findings to engineering audiences. We have disseminated our findings extensively to professionals who can use our results to inform the creation and implementation of intervention programs that can bolster women and Latinx’ persistence in engineering. Further, we have delivered invited presentations at the University of Minnesota (Department of Psychology Colloquium Series), St. Mary’s College of Maryland (Department of Psychology Lecture Series), University of Missouri (Distinguished Lecture Series), and University of North Dakota (STEM Café, Faculty Lecture Series). Finally, we have trained 24 URM psychology students. These RAs have developed expertise in theoretically-driven research, understanding the career issues of women and Latinxs in engineering, and grant development. Their involvement has led to four dissertations and one master’s thesis on Latinx and women in engineering. Two former RAs are current faculty developing research lines on URMs in engineering. The PIs have mentored graduate students with interests in the career development of URMs. Our project website (http://nsfengineerstudy.org) contains a summary of the project and outputs.
